From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introducing a New Approach to Search: Novelty Search
	(New Paper)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=bBuUVxGAszNhQNB27kLCTAlPSIjgEhFHT_ukzyxzYl9QiN5TvTrc5qt6EaQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Hi,

> But is this really true?  As I mentioned, we have run novelty search
> in these mazes where the behavior is around 400 dimensions, which come
> from (x,y) on each timestep.  

While this is encouraging, I don't think you've actually tested "full"
dimensions. If it requires 100.000 tests to solve a maze with a size of
NxN pixels, a maze of NxNxN voxels should require (sqrt(100.000))^3=31.6
million tests, simply because you now have a vastly larger space to
search. Add another dimension to that and you're cozying up to 10 billion
tests. 

The fact that storing every visited x,y over 400 timesteps does't require
many more tests indicates that the path space for NEAT is fairly uniform
in these tests, though it certainly could have exploded, it didn't.
Probably for the reasons you suggest of complexification, try a sligthly
different path and you end up somewhere else, filling up the search space
of possible ending positions pretty fast.

This wouldn't and couldn't happen in a volume (for lack of a better word)
with many more dimensions. 

> Thus the space of possible trajectories is astronomical.  Yet even so,
> with that type of characterization, there was no performance hit (in
> experiments not yet published).  What do you think that implies?  Do
> you really feel that one astronomical space is more expensive than
> another?  For example, we might have a 3 dimensional maze with a
> similar number of timesteps, but that would simply increase the
> dimensionality of behavior from 400 to 1200.  Those are still both
> extremely high dimensional characterizations.  If moving from 2
> dimensions to 400 doesn't hurt, why would moving from 400 to 1200?  

I do think that the two spaces are uncomparable. I've tried to speculate
on why, but I think that your explanation ultimately is the correct one,
it's related to complexification. But adding another true dimension
increases the problem search space by a great factor.

> However, we are talking about comparing already-characterized
> behaviors, so the "n" in O(n^2) is not the same "N" that is in the
> O(N) for number of evaluations.  

No, N grows steadily and at one point the test of whether the solution is
truly novel will take longer than the actual test itself. granted, you'd
be in the range of hundreds of millions of tests before that happens, but
beyond that point, progress will steadily decrease. Actually, it steadily
decreases from the first novelty inovation, but too slowly to be noticable.

> Comparing two strings is not as expensive as evaluating 
> an individual.  

Two strings, no, comparing 1 string to N strings will become expensive for
very large N.

O(N^2) looks good for small N. Then, suddenly; whammo! Simplest method,
using a bucket hash method with K buckets, you reduce the problem from
O(N^2) to O((N/K)^2), which is still O(N^2). So for large N, you're still
stuck. That's for very large searches though.

with regards,
mattias
